title: Amazing Onboarding Experience
pros: I have worked for top companies over a 30 year career, but I've never had such a positive onboarding experience as I've had here with Invitation Homes. On my very first day, I was surprised by the fact that people already knew who I was and what I was hired to do. All of my required equipment was set up for me before I got there and there was already a training plan in place to help me learn about my job in addition to learning about the company and it's culture. The online training program has been exceptional. There are trainings available for all aspects of my job. Any HR questions I may have are easily accessible and if I can't find it myself, I can email someone who responds almost immediately. There are regular Zoom and/or "Teams" meetings where we identify issues and work through them. Every week there is a company wide meeting where every employee is made aware of the companies vision and goals, in addition to where we currently stand. In the short time I've been there, I've had great interaction with the team and find it refreshing to work with people who display a high level of professionalism while at the same time are willing to take a moment to have fun and light hearted conversation that has made me feel genuinely welcomed to the team. I've worked for companies in the past who claim they love their people...I feel like this company truly does!
cons: Every company has it's flaws, but so far I have not had any experiences I would categorize as a "Con".

title: Best in the industry
pros: It took a lot of years and a lot of growing pains for IH to get where they are today and as one of the original crew I speak from experience, there's no one in the industry who's further along in process structure and operations, period. I have since worked for a few competitors and they are where IH was about 2-3 yrs ago, no joke it's noticeable. Take it from someone who spent many years helping pave the way for IH's future workforce, if you're looking for a job that's one dimensional, or won't require you to perform, IH is not the place for you. There's going to be lots (and lots) of volume but if you can manage it and find your flow you'll never be bored lol, seriously you'll have a long career with loads of job security. You'll also learn a ton about real estate and property management and accomplish things you didn't even know you were capable of.
cons: 1) In the larger markets, IH really needs more middle management roles. The staff need support and residents often call and ask for Managers. If there were more middle managers, senior leadership would have support to focus on proactive forecasting and performance metrics for their departments. The day to day operational tasks can be heavily administrative and time consuming, exempt managers are working around the clock 24/7 no balance.

title: A Circus Of Failure
pros: Weekends off, paid holidays, nothing else but I apparently have to have more than 4 words and a comma.
cons: Start your day at 7:30 in the morning and for the next 8 hours, question why you're still working at Invitation Homes. Your average work day will consist of various enthralling activities including (but not limited to): responding to e-mails from confused vendors and angry tenants, attending yet another pointless meeting where the entire office is told exactly how terrible they are at their jobs, wondering how your boss got his/her job in the first place considering he/she has the cognitive ability of a fence post, and spending at least half the day trying to remember what your life was like before the mind-numbing black hole of despair that is Invitation Homes. Management is terrible, they treat their employees like dirt. Other employees will constantly throw each other under the bus to avoid being blamed for something they are personally at fault for. Also, don't ever expect a raise. The salaries aren't exactly terrible, but you will be doing far more work than you will be compensated for. Don't expect much over-time either, they frown upon that very much. They will hire just about anyone who comes in for an interview regardless of qualifications. There is basically no training period either. You get hired on a Monday and you're thrown into the water with no life jacket by that following Friday.

Coming to this company helped me meet so many friends that I now consider family and it also changed the trajectory of my entire life. title: Defining an industry
pros: The single family rental industry is still young, but IH has done an amazing job of becoming the largest in size, while maintaining a higher quality product (the rental home) than its competitors. Since the industry is still in its infancy there is plenty of opportunity for bright individuals to make their mark on ways to improve the business if they are willing to put in the extra effort.
cons: Because it's a young industry there's no preset roadmap to the end goals of the company. The only thing consistent is change, so you have to be able to roll with the punches and adapt quickly. It's not for everyone, especially those that don't adapt well to changing timelines, goals and pressures.

Keep up the great work and again I applaud Upper Managements drive, leadership, mentoring and continued support each day. Thank you for developing such an amazing and diverse team and culture.

title: The good and the bad...

Note: this is not a long term employer, you will need to go somewhere to advance in a property management career.
cons: The pay is terrible for the amount of work and care is expected of you. You are better off managing in a multifamily setting then this company. You will be expected to manage over 900 single family homes for the same salary you could make managing 150 apartments that are all located on one property, not scattered across a whole city and suburbs.

title: Toxic Culture
pros: Flexible schedules and remote opportunities are available.
cons: Leaders in the marketing department put themselves and their own career advancement before their direct reports. Little to no career growth opportunities if you are considered a junior associate. Bad communication, disorganized, toxic leaders, and team issues are swept under the rug. High rate of turnover in junior associates due to poor treatment and low pay. Teammates have been yelled at in front of others, junior associates are embarrassed and made to cry frequently, and not treated as adults. If you express interest in what you want to do with your career, don't expect to be listened to. They will put you where it benefits them, even if you don't have experience in the area, then punish you for not immediately excelling and won't allow you time/resources to develop your skills.

title: Do as I Say, Not as I Do
pros: Great pay and decent benefits.
cons: I must admit I was happy with Invitation Homes when I first came on board. It’s odd how quickly the environment changed, which was mostly triggered by how management (of all levels) operates or lack thereof. If YOU’RE in their CLIQUE, you have it made. PTO, Flexibility, Ethics, Rules and Policies: They do NOT lead by example and do not live up to the workplace culture or values. It’s all about the “buddy system”! They don’t not care if their employees are overworked. Employees are concerned with his or her own spot on the company's constantly-shifting roles. Rental homes: I would not rent a house from Invitation Homes and if anyone solicited my opinion about renting, I would say “stay far away”! Maintenance issues are not resolved in a timely manner.

title: Here for the Long Haul!!
pros: This company values their employees. Associate Care is a top priority. They want us to feel valued, appreciated and most of all respected. They listen to employee feedback and make changes swiftly to make sure we know we are heard. They have introduced "Flex Scheduling" allowing employees to work in a hybrid environment that allows for us to work at home and still meet the needs of the business. I still have about 15 years before I can retire and that will be with Invitation Homes. NO Salary or Job Title can persuade to leave IH.
cons: NOT REALLY A CON, simply a suggestion - While I understand the value of Diversity and its impact on the work place, we need to remain as ONE TEAM - UNITED. NO need for separate groups, we all feel valued and work better when blended :)

title: Honesty, Integrity, Value, Quality, Service
pros: The front-line employees such as outside agents, local call center, portfolio managers and similar staff want to provide quality service to the tenant base. Overall, they are people with solid work ethic who believe in beginning and completing tasks necessary to provide service, quality, value--you get the picture-- to a tenant base.
cons: Management is corrupt because the company goals are antithetical to honesty, integrity, value, quality, and service. The company goal is singular: profits for shareholders far removed from the likes of residential property rentals. So, the goal is to automate what can be automated. Employ highly unqualified and unlicensed personnel, cut costs where possible...mostly in customer service and quality repairs. Rent increases and evictions, irrespective of property condition, location and company dysfunction. For now, the economic climate provides a safe haven and profitability for this culture.

cons: Other than the local traffic we deal with to get to the offices…I do not have one con I can think of about my current employment and company.

Cannot continue to use the excuse of "we are still a young company"...

title: Not a bad place to work, but definitely has its challenges
pros: Great Benefits with matching 75% 401K, great people to work with, always plenty of work to do, understanding supervisors as long as your work is done, always a pot luck
cons: Not what you know but who you know that increases your staying power, constant fear of losing your job due to layoffs, no real opportunity for advancement, no accountability for not following operational procedures, only care that things are done....not that they are done right

title: Trying hard
pros: IH has a number of driven, bright, and effective leaders throughout the organization. This is a great sector with excellent assets and a relatively scalable platform.
cons: Politics tends to get in the way of the best decisions - and "not invented here" is a frequent idea killer. The merger in 2017/2018 was a culture clash but only because decisions were delayed as everyone was coddled. I wouldn't recommend to a friend only based upon what I know of my old department - but the company is solid and there are a lot of good people here.

title: My Experience
pros: It’s being six years with Invitation Homes. The company really care to keep good people. For me, there’s no better company to work with in the real estate industry. The pay is the best compared to any other RE company. Management is always flexible, and willing to work with you. I had situations where I needed to take some personal time off, and they would work with me without skipping a heart beat. They run the office like a big family. People that usually aren’t team players and don’t care for their peers, won’t go far. However, if you are a hard work and care about people, this is the right place.
cons: It’s a big company that has a lot of people. Sometimes, conflicts may arise between departments. However, management is always on top of that.

title: Limitless opportunity
pros: - Limitless opportunity for career growth to those who are dedicated - Great Benefits -Family-like environment I've been here 4 years and would not want to work at any other company. I started as a field-level associate and worked my way up the position ladder. If you work hard and dedicate yourself it will not go unnoticed, everyone is given an opportunity to make a difference and drive the company to the greater good as well as advance through different roles.
cons: This is a fast-paced environment that is going to challenge you, but if your ready for an adventure this is the place to be.

title: Great Company - Great Benefits
pros: Working at Invitation Homes is a wonderful experience as the teamwork and support staff is always available. The benefits are a large plus as well. Definitely a company that stands out in this industry.
cons: The only downside to Invitation Homes is the unreasonable expectation for the positions, including the non-flexible pay but expectation for personal time sacrifice and flexibility on the employee for the work/life balance. The bonus structure change is a perfect example.....more work on each employee, with lower bonus pay and less incentive. Unfortunately, typical for this industry.

title: Can't recommend
pros: Pretty good benefits and nice co-workers, different busines model than most real estate companies.
cons: First of all no company is perfect, especially a 3 Year-old company. With that sidenote, there is a unusual amount of consist change in senior management, who typically brings in their own people. They aren't straight-forward (smile while lying to you and have personal agendas; typically causing fear, resentment, lack of motivation and heavy turn-over. Simply said, it doesn't really matter hard you try or contribute, you really don't matter. Someone else that is fresh and enthusiastic is there to take your place, again and again. But, we will be gone too, just with a very lucrative package.

title: Venture Capital Owned - out for profit above all else
pros: Pay is decent. Benefits are good. If you are tired of seeing your family, you're in luck. You will be working so many hours you'll barely recognize them before too long.
cons: If you actually like having a life outside of work, forget about it. No work-life balance. In an effort to increase their profits, the venture capitalists who own Invitation Homes have cut staff to the bone. The work didn't go away, just the people. Be prepared to take on the workload of 2 - 3 people. Get ready to be screamed at by a lot of unhappy residents, too.

title: Unbearable workload
pros: Good benefits, hybrid schedule, PTO, bonus
cons: The workload over the years is completely unmanageable and you are not paid competitively to other companies with less workload. High turnover. Upper management hears your concerns and it goes out the window. The houses are not ready when residents move in and they leave it to management to deal with angry residents. Does patchwork repairs and do not do any right unless a resident escalates just to save money. We spend less time on actually managing properties and operate like a call center.

title: Overall strong company with growth opportunity for those willing to work.
pros: Pay and benefits are very good. Strong financial backing, good growth trajectory, experienced senior management who understand property management and will be able to take this company to the next level.
cons: Lack of communication on the part of senior management about company direction. The only constant here is change, which isn't all bad, but when combined with the lack of communication can be frustrating at times.

title: I was a temp, but they really are like a family there, and treated me like family for the time that I worked with them
pros: Tight knit community. I felt like family. I was paid generously even as a temp.
cons: I was there for about 5 months as a temp. My biggest gripe is that they fired my supervisor, and as a result meant that I would no longer be working there. Im ok with all of that, but I wish they at least would have been honest about it with me. The last day I was there, I assumed I would continue working. They never felt the need to contact me to tell me they no longer need me.

title: Leasing Agent
pros: Plenty of work to do, listings issued without prospecting, good people that care about more than just the bottom line, good executive level that respects the opinions of agents.
cons: Massive reduction in compensation from where the position started, to the point where the work done goes without appropriate compensation. Previously was an attitude of collaboration with cooperating brokers to get properties leased as quickly as possible with maximum effective rent, now an area where internal and cooperating brokers are in competition over a much smaller total compensation, with almost 90% of the compensation going to the broker that brings the tenant, leaving the internal agent with well below minimum wage for the amount of work going into getting that property leased.

title: Invitation Homes is a roller coaster of fun and learning!
pros: Learning and growth opportunities are abundant at Invitation Homes! My background is in Banking, and I have, with the help of my very talented coworkers, learned more about Property Management than I ever imagined in my short time employed by Invitation Homes. I am amazed (almost daily) by Invitation Homes' fast-paced yet support-oriented culture...!
cons: I cannot think of any cons at this time! The Invitation Homes Management teams offer an open-door policy, which is helpful when or if an employee needs guidance! There are NO stupid questions!

title: We're All so Lucky!
pros: The company is focused on a work-life balance and has a family oriented environment that promotes commodity amongst associates. As a leading company in the industry, it supports and encourages innovation and potential for growth in the years to come. Overall, this is a great job to have. We're compensated competitively for our performance with incentives and the company shows a strong sense of concern for our total well being.
cons: As so many people are happy in their roles with the company, there is a longer wait to advance within the company. Obvious issues and concerns are often are consistently overlooked or undermined as they may not affect the general population.

title: Happy Employee
pros: Invitation Homes (IH) is a great company that promotes within. I started as a temporary employee in 2015. Since I started with the company, I've earned two promotions. They recognize and reward dedicated employees with great incentives. IH offers great and competitive pay. The company supports work/life balance. Management is very supportive, the office environment feels like you are working with family, and overall, I am very happy working at Invitation Homes. The company genuinely cares about its employees, is always looking for ways to ensure we are happy, and goes above and beyond for its employees. I highly recommend working at Invitation Homes.
cons: The workload can be very demanding during certain times of the month. Would like better health and supplement insurance coverage

title: Great Company
pros: Working at Invitation Homes has been a real pleasure. From day one the company has been very proactive in training, making sure that I am equipped with all the necessary tools and state of the art training to perform my job at the highest level. The office support both locally and nationally have been superb. The benefit package is strong and superior to most other companies I have seen over the past two decades. Their commitment to a diverse workplace has and will continue to be at the forefront. Very welcoming place to work.
cons: I haven't experienced a downside with the company.

title: The sky is the limit!
pros: So much respect and transparency for the staff and the residents, from the CEO to local leadership. So many mentors and leaders willing to take you under their wing and teach you anything they know to grow you. Company and local VPO set clear career path options and supports while driving performance daily.
cons: As with any ever changing business, the focus pivots weekly, sometimes multiple times a week. Can be hard to manage and easy to get into holes but leadership always turns around, listens to staff feedback and work to make it better next time. We always grow more successful through the chaos!

title: Management lost sight of what was important
pros: The staff that remains are made up of some of the best people I've ever worked with. They give their all to IH and genuinely care about the residents. It was a family environment in the office.
cons: New Senior Management ruined that family environment. Everyone began despising their job and it's not an exaggeration to say that no one in the office enjoys working at IH anymore. The company has sold their soul for their bottom line.

title: Poor treatment of employees in corporate office
pros: Learn to do new things. Great opportunity to get your feet wet. I think the CEO means well and wants the employees to be happy.
cons: Work many hours for little pay. I am making almost double since I left. I was spoke down to many times and treated with disrespect. There is no such thing as work life balance. No room for advancement since corporate office has such a small number of people.

title: Better trained, experienced, and more mature people managers needed! Bait & switch on newly-created positions.
pros: I didn't have a positive experience. The only pro might be that this is a small, tight-knit group.
cons: Be careful when accepting a newly-created position. You will be tasked with lower-level busy work. Not the job you interviewed for. No time to assimilate or course correct. Dysfunctional tactics like extreme micromanagement, control over communicating with business partners, and eggshell walking, condescension and inability to manage up, passive-aggressive behavior and gaslighting when they want you off the team. The insurance didn't even cover one of my (common) medications I take regularly. This has never happened in 15 years of insurance coverage with this Rx.

title: Corporate Scum
pros: The job i did was great! i loved the responsibility and freedom to come up with creative solutions.
cons: Invitation Homes doesn't care about its employees. They hired a ton of people to rehab all their homes so they could get them on the market. As soon as they were done they laid off every rehab department across the country, in all 13 markets. The only thing IH cares about is bulking up its portfolio and selling its stock on the markets. It a blood sucking company that will chew you up and spit you out. They are renting these houses above market value saying they are "newly renovated" but the work is bad and the materials are even worse. They would even fight tooth and nail not to pay the contractors for the work they ALREADY did. Do not work for this company.

title: Project Mgr.
pros: They are nasty ,treat people with disrespect and never let you give your opinion enough said
cons: They are very difficult to work for and have no problem working any hours or any day (I lost my wife recently )so what ever you need me to do I will be there)I worked for Skaf /Best interior for 15 years This is my passion I love this work ask any one (my References) they will tell you the same I just need an oppertunity

title: Rampant backstabbing and politics
pros: You get some terrible free food and some snacks now and then. You also get front row seat to senior officials being catty with each other and constantly one upping each other. At the Director - SVP level, most people are highly insecure and always bad mouthing each other and it is very amusing. You will learn to reach Olympian level at the assigning blame to somebody else
cons: Run away as fast as you can unless you are starving to death. Rumor mill runs on steroids here so keep you head down. Accountants are leaving in hoards but the Chief turns a blind eye to it and keeps her eyes solidly fixed on her own bonus check

title: Low end rejects employee and poor management
pros: Some of the people are nice but most are rude will curse you out,threaten you and management does nothing. Very unprofessional enviroment. No opportunity for growt. Política and favoritism.Job repititious.Most agents are very unprofessional. Dont waste your time unless your desperate other than that.7-10 people packed in different hot offices on top of each other.fire marshall has been their several times because of complaint. Overworked unappreciated and under paid. If you help make an agent 10000 a week you should get paid at least 1000 per week because he Did all the hard Leg work. Keep in moms you have 7_10agent that you handle with at least20applications a piece a day. Itscrazy.Doesnt pay enough to deal with the Office bullies.
cons: Pay,bullies,unprofessional start and management,no skill building,no Dion for growth,politics favoritism and a whole por of thugs.

title: Senior Managment
pros: Start up company Fast paced innovative Technology driven
cons: I was the 1st employee when IH open this office and the folks that started the company should've never left!! I know their departure was part of the plan but they were the guys that all of us WANTED to work for. The new regime (senior leadership/Dallas) are worried about 2 things, "numbers" and themselves. Best thing that could happen, IH goes public and LF(COO) gets booted out!!

title: Sweat Shop with Benefits
pros: Nice people, good PTO, Starbucks coffee, making good strides in resident satisfaction.
cons: No work-life balance. The office culture is a pressure cooker. The underlying message is to stay late all the time. Office is overcrowded with cubicles in every viable space. Zero privacy Churning all day, very long days, is pushing people to work ineffectively and burn out quickly. If people last over year, they are zombies. It shows in every possible way.

title: Could be worse.
pros: Free food/coffee. Executives seem to care quite a bit about company culture and plan events. Good benefits/PTO policy
cons: In accounting, you can't take part in most corporate events because you live for month end. Forget about taking vacation days during active close. Don't expect to be able to take more than one week vacation at a time even if they can ever keep fully staffed. Turnover has been a nightmare and the accounting software is a steep learning curve if you have not used it before. There seems to be very little internal mobility to managerial positions.

title: Excellent Experience at IH
pros: Salaries are fair and benefits are adequate. With the exception of a few people playing politics and a department that has the atmosphere of a kindergarten classroom, the team atmosphere is great and the people are fantastic to work with.
cons: The early hiring practices were perplexing due to being hired to work in a real estate investment firm with little or no real estate experience. This seemed to cause some issues at first, but things seem to be working themselves out as their lack of market and other relevant knowledge became obvious.

title: Keeping it Real
pros: Enjoy working with great people. Downtown location very close to Dart Rail. in the Bank of America building.
cons: Too much change with no clear direction explained to staff. Staff needs to be informed so that we can be part of the interactive process. If our voice is not material, then why should we be invested in the success of the company. We need to be a part of the team to be able to move the team and company forward.

title: Work Hard, Make Money and Have Fun!
pros: Amazing growth opportunities with vast learning opportunities. Has work-life balance and accommodates employee needs. Most importantly appreciates their employees and the work they do. Management is always looking for ways to grow and improve the company. Great people, good benefits, flexible schedule that works into my family life. I love Invitation Home, I love my residents and I love my job!
cons: I love the company and have not found anything major that hinders the excellent work environment.

title: the epitome of bad corporate america
pros: the company itself is great, the business strategy is positive, employee benefits are good. leaders put in the effort to make it a good company for its employees at a high level
cons: the people in it, it is a company with very strong office politics where you only seem to be safe if you conform to an unethical behavior. most people are bullied and pushed into intimidation so the problems are never brought to the light. the few that try to bring awareness don't make it or never succeed within the organization.

title: Great Company to Work, with a Family touch!
pros: -Great friendly, family oriented environment -Pay is decent -Growth Opportunities if you are willing to put in the work, just like most other companies -Wonderful Management team/Director -Benefits are decent -Bonuses/Incentives provided by the actual department sporadically
cons: -Pay could be a little better, especially when it comes to pay increases -Working hours (mainly the actual days you are scheduled) -Training is not as hands on and in depth for all learning styles, seems to be rushed a little

title: It's always a great day at Invitation Homes!
pros: As a blanket statement, IH is an incredibly warm, welcoming, and attentive organization. The leadership is second to none. IH truly takes care and supports every employee, big and small, equally - which in turn pours out into the way we serve each individual resident. I'm honored to be part of this team.
cons: Because no day looks the same with residents, there are many unanticipated circumstances in which are hard to structure training around. There are times where you learn as you go and call for one to be creatively solution oriented. However, there is always a strong support system behind you.

title: Great Opportunities
pros: Invitation Homes is still growing. As they grow there are numerous opportunities to move up or over promoting career growth. They have adopted a flexible work schedule program that allows employees to work from home part of the week based on performance. This is a great way to promote more of a life-work balance. The leadership provides open communication and feedback and really want their employees involved. It's a great company to be a part of and I look forward to what's next.
cons: As with any company that is still growing there are challenges and changes that happen frequently. Change is good. It shows that we are always moving towards something better.

title: Room for a lot of improvement
pros: Most of my co-workers are great to work with
cons: Lack of organization structure. Favoritism is the only way to get ahead in this company. People aren't hired or promoted based upon their skill level and work ethic.

title: Excellent Organization and Culture
pros: I have worked with Invitation Homes for close to 9 years and have had nothing but a positive experience. We are always looking to improve to set ourselves apart as a best in class organization. It's a family-like atmosphere with a positive culture and the best part about the company is the people. Every day brings a new challenge and the fast paced environment brings much needed energy and excitement to my career.
cons: There aren't any detractors that come to mind. We move fast, but often of necessity as we are always looking to enhance our associate and customer experience.

title: There are opportunities here
pros: This is a young company that encourages the exchange of ideas. We are growing so fast and that fact is exciting. The people I work for are at the top in their field. There is an open-door policy starting with the C-level management.
cons: Again, the company is still young and grasping to form an identity. We need to incorporate a more relaxed culture when it comes to team-building events.

title: Corporate Employee
pros: I work on a fun positive team, love interacting with other teams as well. Corporate is professional, but not stuffy. Good monthly employee events, like National Ice Cream Day celebration. Fast-paced, building its foundation since it is still a relatively new company, so lots of opportunity to make a difference.
cons: Business changes frequently, but needs to in order to make improvements to the business. Departments are now getting better at communicating with one another, which helps in the decision making and change process.

title: Three months and it feels like I have been here forever (in a good way!)
pros: I love my new job! It is fast paced, great team, comparable salary and benefits package. My divisional president is supportive, knowledgeable and wonderful to work for; I see why his ex-employees gave him such glowing remarks.
cons: Its not really a con for me but there are constant changes so you must be flexible!

title: Survival of the Coolest
pros: Great Pay. Ok benefits. They feed you a lot...
cons: Manager sleeping with employees. Higher ups knew about it and did nothing. Now over 30 people have lost their job due to the department shutting down. Lots of favoritism. The new manager is great though. This review is based on my experience with the last managers who I spent the most time with while employed.

title: It was a very enjoyable place to work.
pros: I had the opportunity to work with some very nice people in an upbeat, fun atmosphere. Management was always coming up with ways to make the company a fun place to work.
cons: truction superintendent

title: Portfolio Manager
pros: Great location in Gilbert. Decent pay and bonuses, both monthly and annually. Great people, all friendly and very hard workers. There is plenty of work but lots of play too!
cons: All the change and instability with management. Very corporate environment, about to go public so we are very thin and they add things every day to your plate. No reviews. No consequences if employees don't do their work.

title: Great Company to work for with lots of opportunity for growth!
pros: I love working here. I've been with the company for about 8 months. It's a great work environment, I love the culture, all of the people I work with are very friendly, and I really feel like the company strives to treat it's employees right and to do what's right for the employee. Also, because it's a new company, and is always growing, there is lots of opportunity for growth with the company.
cons: It's a new company so things are always changing on a daily basis. However, it keeps you on your toes. :)

title: The Sky is the Limit!
pros: Endless growth potential, premium technology and tools, brilliant corporate support, flexible, and we serve with heart and integrity every day. If you are someone who wants to be a part of a team and work toward common goals, we want you here! We are filled with bright individuals who all add value to our environment and for our customers.
cons: IH is consistently evolving to become the best in the market, which may come with growing pains. Tough times never last, but tough people do!

title: Portfolio Operations Director
pros: The benefits are worthwhile when the opportunity arises and you can use and having a 401k is a positive. Working alongside the other Portfolio Operations Directors is helpful and keeps the momentum charged.
cons: There are challenges and obstacles that prevent us from reaching out to inner upper management and they also lack the knowledge and professionalism.

title: Stable Node Shop
pros: Invitation Homes is a large and stable business with a growing IT and development team. The team is friendly and open to new ideas and the process is largely democratic. Sheldon McGee is an OG and is awesome to work with. It is very easy to maintain a healthy work-life balance at IH. There are always new problems to solve.
cons: Like most development shops, process can be burdensome, though it is constantly evolving.

title: Best Company - Very Happy
pros: The entire company, from the employees to the local and corporate management teams, all genuine and thoughtful. There is a team spirit at IH with the same goals throughout the regions. Everyone want to grow the company, give the residents the best home and customer service, and help their co-workers. It is truly a group effort.
cons: Work space is needed. Everyone is in cubicles and it makes it very hard to focus and get reports completed with constant movement and conversations.

pros: ITS A JOB AND AT LEAST I CAN GET HOME AT A DESCENT HOUR.
cons: overworked and under paid... Good luck getting promoted... Management is nothing more than a bunch of over payed morons.

title: IH is a mill
pros: work with some intelligent people. nice office space. free snacks, the occasional free leftovers.
cons: lack of training, long hours, poor pay, terrible benefits, "do the work and keep quiet" mentality, severe office politics, IH hires to fill and never promotes within, very high employee turnover. forget about having a life outside of work- you will work 6-7 days a week and get paid pennies on the dollar.

title: Maintenance working for Maintenance
pros: I've been in multifamily housing for over 14 years, 10 as a supervisor on different properties. I've dealt with the on-call the pushy managers, the constant feeling of never catching up and repetition of the same thing at the same place everyday. It's what I knew and honestly something I am good at. I was extremely nervous and a bit apprehensive about switching to a newish career field. The first few weeks were odd while I was waiting for the ball to drop doing paperwork and training. Then I got my van, then I got my schedule, I had a few hiccups but then found out if you ask for help here you get it! The support system is amazing with invitation, It's corporate but a corporate that I never imagined, they send out surveys but then you see things change with your input. Not only that but maintenance is actually its own department, There is NO ONE TELLING you to do or how to do your job that hasn't done it before. It's an amazing breath of fresh air. There is still on-call here but you go months in between your on-call vs once a month or more. All of the on-call is filtered through the supervisors so you rarely hear anything. This company allows and promotes you having a personal life!!! They trust you here, there's no micromanagement and again the greatest thing if you ask for help you get it. You have two amazing supervisors that are constantly available for advice or to jump in and lend a hand and phenomenal Regional that is involved with all of it. Again the regional started as a maintenance tech, so you really do have people that understand your job here helping you with it, Not barking at you how to do it!!! This is a good company it's big enough for room for advancement and they recognize when you bust your butt and do a good job. Most of the time these reviews only come from two types of people those that are bitter or those that get roped into them. If you take this job you will end up working together with me as well as a great team of techs. I'll tell you the same thing. Again, I cant stress enough that this company actually wants you to have a life and does everything possible to make sure your time is your time!
cons: There's still on call but it's minimal (really minimal)

title: Not nice at all
pros: You can learn about the business from this company. And they will teach you all that you need to know. And some of the people their were the best to work with
cons: The President of the company is super rude. Would only speak to you if you were talking to someone one that she wanted to talk to. She would walk pass you and not say good morning or good night. And the only people she would say good job to would be the managers. But we made them look good.

title: Great opportunities, growing pains
pros: If you take initiative you can learn a lot about the business. Work from home/flexible schedule for some positions Decent benefits, but a bit pricey Fast work environment Overall, people want to do a good job
cons: Poor people management in a lot of teams Flip-flopping in decision making and big initiatives are very common. There is a general fear of making decisions by management due to micromanaging from upper-management. Pass the buck is the name of the game. They promote a lot of people because they are good at their job and you end up having a case of "promoted to your level of incompetence." The corporate culture is not very welcoming. Teams don't interact much with each other, so unless you are part of one of the bigger ones you work on your little island. Poor communication leads to duplicate work between teams. Project management for large initiatives consists of throwing everyone and the kitchen sink into a project and scheduling hundreds of hours for meetings in people's calendar when 90% of the people don't have relevant input for the project. Very inconvenient location in downtown Dallas, commuting there is a nightmare If you drive, add an extra 10 mins to your commute each way just to get to and from the parking lot. If you take the DART include 10 -15 mins extra each day due to the very frequent delays when the trains reach the downtown corridor, as well as, get comfortable with having a lot of homeless begging you for money. It breaks your heart, and some of them can get quite aggressive.

title: Fast paced company with a lot of future opportunities!
pros: They are able to adapt and adjust quickly because still small in nature. Great team that I am currently on! My boss is positive and supportive and almost everyone at the executive level has an open door policy.
cons: Moving too fast, so sometimes have to catch up with policies, processes, etc. and company is trying to figure out the culture.

title: Great people, great job, but broken promises .
pros: We have a great staff in the office and out in the field . The work is steady and effortless, but yet challenging .
cons: A lot of broken promises. Salary does not change. They dont give you the proper tools to do your job efficiently

title: Leasing Consultant
pros: I was with the former Waypoint Homes and do not know much of the new Invitation Homes. However, I would say that it was a great culture, we delivered a great product and upper management truly supported the local teams.
cons: ultant

title: I Bleed Green!
pros: Great pay, great benefits, exceptional culture, amazing talent, brilliant mentors, top technology, and strong leadership.
cons: This is not the place for those who do not want to put in the work in order to grow. You can go very far here if you apply yourself but, this is not for those who just want to show up and collect a check. Invitation Homes has a standard which is why we are best in class but, this job is not for the bare minimum performer. Hard work, however, is always rewarded and recognized.

title: Growing Company
pros: Invitation Homes has helped me develop skills that will help me succeed in the future. I don’t believe I would have had the success that I have now, had it not been for the leadership that the Phoenix office has provided me. Invitation Homes has consistently pushed me to become better, and succeed in every way possible. I will miss the day to day office conversations and the occasional game of ping pong.
cons: The bonus structure is good but needs to be more focused on individual performance.

title: Hard Work Pays Off-Phoenix Location
pros: Teamwork is at its finest. Upper Management is very involved, they are your biggest supporters. Flexibility . Your opinion is valued. There are no slackers. You are expected to work your bottom off but it pays off. This company is leading the way in property management.
cons: There are constant changes in policies and procedures.

title: Dead-end Despite the so-called Company Culture
pros: There's usually some kind of free food/potluck every other month. There's a lot of chit-chat and goofing around in most departments.
cons: Compensation is unbalanced, but most don't know because of a hard line no-share rule about pay rate. Company feels that company-branded trinkets (coffee mug, mouse pad, etc) is the way to gain loyalty. Hourly employees are expected to round to the minute. There is an expectation of working off the clock.

title: The best people to work with!
pros: I never thought the people that I work with would make such a difference. Invitation Homes has the best employees that all care about each other.
cons: There are really no cons. If you hate real estate then you will probably hate invitation homes.

title: Great place to work
pros: Have been with the company for three and a half years. Invitation home has been great family to me. They take a very good care of their employees. Awesome benefits and pay grade. You will easily be promoted when you prove yourself. Hands down this is the best company I have worked for in my entire life. They will spend the time to better advance your skills. They provide you with all the tools to succeed
cons: truction superintendent

title: Great people, great leadership & great experiences.
pros: This is by far the best company I have ever worked for. The company ethics are great, the people are driven and passionate about what they do, and everyone has the highest commitment to our clients and the company as a whole. I couldn't be happier.
cons: Not much to say about this TBH.

title: Fast paced with plenty of growth opportunities
pros: Growing company, great co-workers and strong work/life balance. Downtown Dallas location is easily commutable. Management team is seasoned in the industry.
cons: Fast paced environment is not for everyone. Growth results in change on a regular basis. If you like a slow pace, this is not the environment for you.

title: The best ever!

title: BIASED, UNBALANCED, SLAVE DRIVERS.
pros: I really wish I had something good to type in this box but really there are zero pros to working here. Hours: Horrible Pay: Horrible for the amount of work and hours put in. Medical Benefits: Too expensive/ very high deductibles and co-pays. Vacation & Paid time off: They are generous with the time but when do you have the time to use it? Even if you are off, you still have to work and residents don't care that you are off. Work Environment: Hostile and highly stressful.
cons: This place will suck the life out of you and you'll want to wake up hoping it was all a dream. Sadly, once you're filing for a divorce, your kids stop respecting you because you're never home and your only friends are the people you work with, then you realize this place has totally ruined your life. However, its perfect for someone who likes a highly stressful work environment and is forced to work 60+ hours a week or more. Since employees under the POD are hourly employees, whatever work they didn't complete, the POD will need to complete or you will get written up and eventually fired if your manager has it out for you. POD's are salaried employees so there is no over time pay and absolutely no time for lunch but they do get bonuses. The bonuses are a joke and the expectations are very vague. One of the bonuses is supposed to be based on performance over a certain time but no one really knows how much time or how they are calculated. They have designed the bonus structure in a way that no one knows exactly how much they will receive. Oh and if you get fired, you don't get the bonus you worked so hard for because "you have to be employed on the day the bonus checks are handed out" This is totally against the law! The other bonus is based on renewals but you can only collect a bonus if you renew more than half of your renewals for a particular month. So if you have 80 renewals in a month, and you only renew 40, there's no bonus for you or anyone on your team that month but if the next month only has 20 renewals and you renew all 20, then you get paid on 9 of them. Sounds fair, huh? You will also have about 1000 properties in your portfolio or more as they fire other POD's adding more to your plate, making it almost impossible to catch up with anything. You are also required to put out fires on files that a previous POD never handled. The main phone is constantly ringing off the hook with angry residents complaining about maintenance issues that in most cases are not fixed because the maintenance department pushes the issues off on the POD to approve. I would never recommend anyone to rent from IH either. The lease application process a joke and the rules changes every time someone from the corporate office in Dallas would come to visit. This place is a ticking time bomb and I am so happy I got my life back before I died there.

title: Out of all the companies I have worked for, this is the worst one yet.
pros: I liked some of my co- workers and benefits were pretty good with three options. When this office first started in 2012 it was really fun, it turned south in the Fall of 2014.
cons: Working here was great in the beginning. We were a team and everyone got along. This branch is on it's third President, and the management team under him has sucked all the fun out. This is place is terrible, absolutely terrible. It is terrible because of the management team. Slowly local management got there way by firing the people they had a personal problem with, but found a lousy excuse to fire them. Now and then, we would see someone get escorted out and no one knew why. Lies were made or bogus reasons to fire someone. People were just waiting for there number to be called, and you just hoped management didn't have a problem with you. You kept you head down and made sure their numbers looked good. Rehab got (and still does) the blame for almost everything. Somehow it was always that departments fault, even if they had absolutely no control over the situation. A manager was let go for some made up reason. He did everything he could everyday to make everyone happy, but I guess it wasn't enough. This was another part of the plot to get the people in power that they wanted. They hired the spouse of someone in the office, which seemed weird to a lot of people, and that person lacked the skills needed for the position. I believe the "Fab 5," finally got there way. I was lucky enough to get out. I put in my two weeks notice on a Sunday and the next morning I was brought into an office with management and they said you can leave right now. I asked why and they responded "company policy." I asked the national HR person, and she said this was a lie. I think management felt I would try and sabotage them, but anyone who knows me, would know I would never do that. I gave IH everything I had, worked hard everyday for two years, and this is how they treated me. I have never felt more disrespected by one person, it wasn't company policy, it was this persons personal decision to treat me this way. Never got a raise in two years, or a review. Bonus was a joke.

title: What a joke.
pros: Benefits are okay. 401k matching is okay. The coffee is free. It's possible that you will make a friend or two amidst the negativity.
cons: Here's some advice for those thinking about pursuing a career with Invitation Homes: don't. Seriously. No amount of money would make this hell hole of a company tolerable. Although it's likely that they aren't offering you much money in the first place, which makes your decision that much easier. Walk away. Now. Every negative review that you read here is completely accurate, and the majority of the positive reviews are absolutely fake - commonly being published after another round of layoffs to combat the inevitable influx of negative reviews. I cannot even come close to overstating the toxicity of the environment here. Some of the rudest, most unprofessional and manipulative people that I have ever had the misfortune of working with have been put in positions of power. Any good morale that ever existed has been completely sucked out of the office - teamwork and collaboration are nonexistent as this company has been reduced to an "every man for himself" environment. Be prepared to play the blame game and to have fingers pointed at you, because this environment is non-conducive to actual problem solving. Rather, most find that their time is better spent passive-aggressively CC'ing upper management on trivial issues and passing the buck on to someone else in order to avoid having to do any actual work. Don't be surprised if you are forbidden from interacting with other departments. Don't be surprised if you go years without a performance review or a raise. Don't be surprised if management starts rumors about you and accuses you of wrongdoing without having any basis whatsoever. And then doubles down on accusations even after you've provided irrefutable proof against them. Corporate HR has completely abandoned the Bellevue branch because it's too far gone. There is no saving this branch unless they decide to address the actual problems and start cleaning house to get rid of the negativity. I've spelled out the problem for you here. If you decide to continue down the road with IH, you won't get any sympathy from me when it all hits the fan. If you value your dignity, your time, and your sanity you should stay far, far away from Invitation Homes.

title: CORRUPT
pros: I was employed in the Chicago market for about 3 years in a secondary management position and met some of the hardest working people I have ever met.The Work place is fast paced and could be a great place to learn the ins and outs of the single family home rental industry.
cons: The local management team is inept and corrupt. I quickly found out that if you are not a (YES MAN) Your in for a miserable workplace environment with the full intention of having you resign or be terminated by whatever means necessary, including but not limited to false accusations and being written up for them, micromanaged to the point of making it impossible to make good business decisions, adding more work than can be effectively handled without working many hours after work. title: Worst company I've ever worked for
pros: Pay, when hired, I thought was great until it became evident that working 60+ hours a week was the rule, not exemption. When actual hours worked are taken to account, pay equates to hardly above minimum wage. Benefits and 401K good though. Only other positive was that all of the employees there dislike the company and atmosphere so much it gave us instant bonding.
cons: This review could easily turn in to a novel, so I will try to keep it brief while also warning of the negative experience this company provides. Having worked in a start up atmosphere previously, I was prepared for some chaos and whirlwind of processes, procedures, changes, etc. However, the number of changes and rules happened at a much higher rate than any start up I've worked at prior. Then, once a change is implemented from Corporate, it may take weeks or months for it to be communicated to the Region, and only is communicated once an employee unknowingly disobeys the new rule/process and is reprimanded for it, that it is then passed along as the correct protocol. Furthermore, each department within the Region runs almost as if it is a separate company, with a blame game and finger pointing culture rather than a unified front working together for a common goal. In addition, as another reviewer posted, socializing with employees of other departments is discouraged, which surely impacts the departments working as individuals rather than a whole. I certainly don't want to come off as a disgruntled employee, and in fact, just the opposite. I've had amazing experiences at other companies. I'm an intelligent, hard working, self motivated employee, and I don't believe it's too much to appreciate recognition for these traits. Invitation Homes did not, and will not, recognize their employees for the value they have, and instead, thinks you are "lucky" to have a job with them. I hope this review was helpful, as it is truly a fair and accurate assessment of not just one, but many employees of this company.

title: RSVP NO to this Invitation
pros: There are some good people that work at the entry level.

The only thing that matters to them is what they can do to make the most money and the only people they care about are upper management. They don't care about good customer service or a quality product. They only care about going public and letting the upper management get rich from that. I was with the company from the beginning. I worked very hard, long hours and brought several great ideas to the table. My ideas were taken by management and used as their own. My hard work and long hours were taken for granite and I was demoted shortly after receiving a promotion. They will fire an employee if they mess up on their time card by a minute but management can have an inappropriate relationship with someone they directly supervise (against company policy) and it doesn't matter. An hourly employee is required to take PTO if they have to leave 15 minutes early but management can take multiple days off and not take any PTO. Upper management will throw anyone under the bus to save their own jobs. They make terrible business decisions such firing almost half the staff because they stopped buying homes and once those employees were gone, they decide to start buying homes again giving all current employees twice as much of a work load. I am a very happy, easy going person who loves life. This company made me a nervous, angry, bitter person who hated going to work. I kept thinking that it was a start up and things would eventually get better. However, in all the years, it only got worse. If you have a good work ethic and care about your job, then I would stay far away from this place. In my opinion, the good reviews were probably people that were paid off.
